subdomain: Motivation & Change — MI and Stage-Based Approaches

questions.stem: A client states, 'I know my drinking is causing problems at work, but I'm not sure I'm ready to stop completely.' According to Prochaska and DiClemente's Transtheoretical Model, this client is most likely in which stage of change?

options.text: Precontemplation
Contemplation
Preparation
Action

questions.explanation: The contemplation stage is characterized by awareness of the problem combined with ambivalence about change. The client acknowledges negative consequences ('causing problems at work') but expresses uncertainty about committing to change ('not sure I'm ready'). Precontemplation involves no awareness of the problem; preparation involves intent to act soon; action involves active behavioral modification.

questions.stem: A motivational interviewing practitioner responds to a client's statement by saying, 'On one hand you enjoy how relaxed alcohol makes you feel, and on the other hand you've noticed your blood pressure and liver enzymes are worsening.' This response best exemplifies which MI technique?

options.text: Simple reflection
Affirmation
Double-sided reflection
Amplified reflection

questions.explanation: A double-sided reflection captures both sides of a client's ambivalence in a single statement, reflecting both the sustain talk and the change talk. This is a complex reflection technique in MI. Simple reflections merely rephrase content; affirmations recognize strengths; amplified reflections exaggerate sustain talk to elicit the client's own correction.

questions.stem: In motivational interviewing, the therapist's natural tendency to try to fix the client's problems and persuade them toward change is referred to as:

options.text: The confrontation trap
The righting reflex
The expert trap
The assessment trap

questions.explanation: Miller and Rollnick identified the righting reflex as the clinician's instinctive desire to fix what is wrong with the client. When clinicians act on this reflex and argue for change, clients are paradoxically pushed toward sustain talk and arguing against change. MI posits that the client, not the therapist, should voice the arguments for change.

questions.stem: During a motivational interviewing session, a client says 'I actually went for a walk three times this week instead of watching TV.' According to DARN-CAT, this statement is best classified as:

options.text: Desire change talk
Commitment change talk
Taking steps change talk
Activation change talk

questions.explanation: In the DARN-CAT framework, 'Taking steps' refers to actions the client has already taken toward change. The client reports having already engaged in the new behavior. Desire ('I want to'), Ability ('I could'), Reasons ('because'), and Need ('I have to') are preparatory change talk. Commitment ('I will') and Activation ('I'm ready to') are mobilizing change talk that precedes actual behavior change.

questions.stem: The decisional balance exercise in motivational interviewing is MOST therapeutically useful for clients in which stage of change?

options.text: Precontemplation
Contemplation
Action
Maintenance

questions.explanation: The decisional balance exercise explores four quadrants: benefits of the status quo, costs of the status quo, benefits of change, and costs of change. This structured exploration of ambivalence is particularly useful during the contemplation stage, where the person is actively weighing the pros and cons of change. In precontemplation the client does not yet see a problem; in action and maintenance the client has already resolved their ambivalence.

questions.stem: Select all statements that accurately describe the 'spirit of MI' as defined by Miller and Rollnick. (Select all that apply.)

options.text: Partnership — MI is conducted 'with' and 'for' the client, not 'to' or 'on' them
Evocation — the clinician draws out the client's own motivations and resources rather than installing them
Confrontation — directly challenging the client's denial is essential to break through resistance
Acceptance — encompasses absolute worth, autonomy support, accurate empathy, and affirmation
Education — providing psychoeducation about the negative consequences of the behavior is the primary mechanism of change

questions.explanation: The spirit of MI comprises four interrelated elements: Partnership, Acceptance, Compassion, and Evocation. MI explicitly avoids confrontation and the expert-driven educational approach. The clinician's role is to elicit the client's own reasons for change rather than providing external arguments or directly challenging denial.

questions.stem: Which of the following are correctly identified as OARS skills in motivational interviewing? (Select all that apply.)

options.text: Open-ended questions that cannot be answered with yes or no
Affirmations that recognize client strengths and efforts
Orienting the client to the stages of change through psychoeducation
Reflections that mirror or rephrase client speech
Summaries that collect and link several client statements together

questions.explanation: OARS stands for Open-ended questions, Affirmations, Reflections, and Summaries. These are the four core micro-skills of MI practice. Orienting to stages of change through psychoeducation is not an OARS skill — MI uses evocation rather than education as its primary approach.

questions.stem: Which of the following are preparatory forms of change talk in the DARN-CAT framework? (Select all that apply.)

options.text: Desire — 'I want to cut back on drinking'
Commitment — 'I will stop drinking this week'
Ability — 'I think I could go a week without a drink'
Need — 'I need to get this under control for my kids'
Taking steps — 'I already poured out the bottles last night'

questions.explanation: DARN (Desire, Ability, Reasons, Need) represents preparatory change talk — language that favors change but has not yet reached the mobilizing level. CAT (Commitment, Activation, Taking steps) represents mobilizing change talk, which is closer to actual behavior change. Research shows that mobilizing change talk is more predictive of actual behavior change than preparatory change talk.

questions.stem: A client in the preparation stage of change is considering starting an exercise program. Which of the following therapist responses are consistent with MI principles? (Select all that apply.)

options.text: Exploring what specific steps the client has already considered taking
Warning the client about the health consequences of continued inactivity
Affirming the client's decision to explore change and recognizing their courage
Asking permission before offering information about exercise options
Assigning a structured exercise regimen and monitoring compliance at the next session

questions.explanation: MI-consistent responses include exploring the client's own ideas about change (evocation), affirming strengths, and asking permission before providing information (respecting autonomy). Warning about consequences reflects the righting reflex, and prescribing a rigid plan undermines the client's autonomy — both violate MI's spirit of partnership and evocation.

questions.stem: According to Prochaska and DiClemente's Transtheoretical Model, which of the following correctly characterize the maintenance stage? (Select all that apply.)

options.text: The individual works to sustain behavioral changes achieved during the action stage
The primary task is preventing relapse to previous behavioral patterns
The stage typically begins approximately six months after consistent behavior change
The individual no longer needs to use any processes of change
The individual has permanently resolved all ambivalence about the changed behavior

questions.explanation: The maintenance stage begins approximately 6 months after consistent action and focuses on sustaining change and relapse prevention. Individuals in maintenance still use processes of change (particularly counter-conditioning, stimulus control, and helping relationships) and may still experience some ambivalence, though it is less intense than in earlier stages. Relapse is considered a normal part of the change process, not a failure.

questions.stem: Match each client statement to the correct type of change talk or sustain talk.

rows.text: 'I want to feel healthier and have more energy'
'I think I could manage going to the gym twice a week'
'I will start meal prepping this Sunday'
'I don't really see the point in changing my diet'

questions.explanation: 'I want to...' reflects Desire (D in DARN). 'I think I could...' reflects Ability (A in DARN). 'I will...' reflects Commitment (C in CAT). 'I don't really see the point' is sustain talk — language favoring the status quo. The MI therapist selectively reflects and reinforces change talk while responding to sustain talk with empathy rather than argument.

questions.stem: Match each MI process (from Miller & Rollnick's four-process model) to its correct description.

columns.text: Establishing rapport and a working relationship
Developing a specific direction for the conversation about change
Eliciting the client's own motivations for change
Formulating a specific plan of action when the client is ready

questions.explanation: Miller and Rollnick's (2013) four-process model organizes MI into sequential, overlapping processes: Engaging (building a working alliance), Focusing (identifying a clear direction for change), Evoking (drawing out the client's own arguments for change — the 'heart' of MI), and Planning (developing commitment and a concrete action plan). Each process builds on the preceding one.

questions.stem: For each stage of change, select ALL appropriate therapeutic strategies. Multiple strategies may apply to each stage.

columns.text: Raise awareness and provide personalized feedback
Develop a specific change plan with concrete steps
Identify relapse triggers and develop coping strategies

questions.explanation: In precontemplation, consciousness raising through personalized feedback is appropriate. In contemplation, both continued awareness-raising and decisional balance exploration are used to help resolve ambivalence. In preparation, the focus shifts to developing a concrete change plan. In maintenance, relapse prevention through identifying triggers and building coping strategies is the primary therapeutic focus.

questions.stem: For each MI response technique, select ALL situations in which it would be MOST appropriately used. Some techniques apply to more than one situation.

columns.text: When the client expresses sustain talk and the therapist wants to elicit self-correction
When the client has made several statements and the therapist wants to link them together
When the client expresses ambivalence with both change and sustain talk
When the therapist wants to demonstrate they heard the client's basic message

questions.explanation: Simple reflections demonstrate basic understanding. Amplified reflections slightly exaggerate sustain talk so the client corrects themselves toward change talk. Double-sided reflections capture both sides of ambivalence and can also address sustain talk by juxtaposing it with previously expressed change talk. Summaries collect and link multiple client statements, often used at transitions or session endings.

questions.stem: Motivational Interviewing was developed by {{blank1}} as a directive, client-centered counseling approach. The core micro-skills are captured by the acronym {{blank2}}. When a client expresses language favoring the status quo, this is called {{blank3}}. MI posits that the clinician should avoid the {{blank4}}, which is the natural tendency to try to fix or persuade the client.

options.text: Miller and Rollnick
Prochaska and DiClemente
de Shazer and Berg
Klerman and Weissman
DARN-CAT
OARS
SFBT
SMART
Change talk
Resistance talk
Sustain talk
Denial talk
Righting reflex
Expert trap
Confrontation cycle
Premature focus

questions.explanation: MI was developed by William R. Miller and Stephen Rollnick. OARS (Open-ended questions, Affirmations, Reflections, Summaries) captures the core skills. Client language favoring the status quo is termed sustain talk (not resistance, which MI avoids labeling). The righting reflex is the clinician's natural but counterproductive urge to fix or persuade.

questions.stem: In the Transtheoretical Model, a person who is unaware of or in denial about their problem is in the {{blank1}} stage. The stage where the person actively weighs the pros and cons of change is {{blank2}}. The {{blank3}} stage involves making small preliminary steps toward change. In the DARN-CAT framework, the preparatory forms of change talk include Desire, Ability, Reasons, and {{blank4}}.

options.text: Precontemplation
Contemplation
Preparation
Denial
Precontemplation
Contemplation
Preparation
Action
Contemplation
Preparation
Action
Activation
Need
Necessity
Commitment
Activation

questions.explanation: The TTM stages progress from Precontemplation (no awareness) to Contemplation (weighing pros/cons) to Preparation (small preliminary steps) to Action (active modification) to Maintenance (sustaining change). DARN represents preparatory change talk: Desire, Ability, Reasons, and Need. Commitment and Activation (along with Taking steps) are the mobilizing forms (CAT).

questions.stem: A 38-year-old man is referred to therapy by his physician after routine bloodwork revealed elevated liver enzymes. He tells the therapist, 'My doctor says I need to cut back, but honestly, I don't think my drinking is that bad. Everyone I know drinks about the same.' However, he also mentions, 'I guess I have been worried about my health lately.' Analyze the clinical dynamics at play.

options.text: Discrepancy between the client's values (health) and current behavior (drinking)
Ambivalence reflected by simultaneous sustain talk and change talk
Severe alcohol use disorder requiring immediate inpatient detoxification
Complete denial of any problem with no openings for therapeutic engagement
Contemplation stage with ambivalence about behavior change
Precontemplation stage with full denial and no awareness of the problem
Action stage with commitment to immediate cessation of alcohol use
Use MI techniques to develop discrepancy and explore ambivalence rather than confronting denial
Avoid the righting reflex and selectively reflect the client's change talk about health concerns
Directly confront the client's minimization and insist he accept the severity of his problem
Immediately implement a relapse prevention plan since the client is in the action stage

questions.explanation: The client exhibits ambivalence typical of the contemplation stage — minimizing the problem (sustain talk) while also expressing health concerns (change talk). The discrepancy between his stated value of health and his drinking behavior creates a therapeutic opening. MI-consistent approaches involve developing this discrepancy, selectively reflecting change talk, and avoiding the righting reflex rather than confronting or prescribing an action plan he is not ready for.

questions.stem: A therapist using MI asks a client who is contemplating smoking cessation to complete a decisional balance exercise. The client lists: benefits of smoking (stress relief, social bonding), costs of smoking (health risks, expense, spouse's complaints), benefits of quitting (better health, saving money), and costs of quitting (irritability, weight gain, losing a coping tool). Analyze the therapeutic dynamics.

options.text: The client has identified multiple personally meaningful reasons for change alongside personally meaningful reasons to maintain the status quo
The exercise allows the client to articulate their own arguments for change without the therapist imposing an agenda
The client is clearly in the precontemplation stage because they listed benefits of continuing to smoke
The therapist should focus only on the costs of smoking and dismiss the stated benefits
Decisional balance as a structured method for exploring ambivalence in the contemplation stage
Cognitive distortion challenging as a method for correcting irrational beliefs about smoking
Behavioral activation to replace smoking with alternative reinforcing activities
Summarize the exercise to highlight the client's own change talk and ask what they make of the balance
Use the client's identified costs of quitting to develop coping strategies when the client is ready to plan
Argue that the costs of quitting are minor compared to the health risks to push the client toward action
Interpret the benefits of smoking as defense mechanisms requiring psychodynamic interpretation

questions.explanation: The decisional balance is a cornerstone MI technique that structures the exploration of ambivalence. It allows the client to generate their own arguments rather than the therapist imposing them (consistent with evocation). The contemplation stage is characterized by this weighing of pros and cons. Clinically, the therapist summarizes the exercise, highlights the client's own change talk, and uses identified barriers to prepare coping strategies when the client is ready — all while avoiding the righting reflex.

questions.stem: Highlight ALL statements that accurately describe principles or techniques of Motivational Interviewing.
questions.passage: In motivational interviewing, the therapist's primary role is to draw out the client's own motivations for change rather than installing them from the outside. [MI is fundamentally a collaborative, person-centered approach that honors the client's autonomy regarding behavior change]. Some practitioners misunderstand MI as a series of techniques, but Miller and Rollnick emphasize that [MI requires the therapist to directly confront the client's denial before any productive work can occur]. A core strategy in MI is the use of reflective listening, and [complex reflections such as double-sided reflections are more advanced than simple reflections and help illuminate the client's ambivalence]. Research on MI has shown that [the quality and frequency of change talk during MI sessions predicts subsequent behavior change outcomes]. However, some critics argue that [MI is only applicable to substance use disorders and has no evidence base for other health behaviors]. Furthermore, [in MI the client, not the therapist, should be the one voicing the arguments for change].

highlightableSegments.text: MI is fundamentally a collaborative, person-centered approach that honors the client's autonomy regarding behavior change
MI requires the therapist to directly confront the client's denial before any productive work can occur
complex reflections such as double-sided reflections are more advanced than simple reflections and help illuminate the client's ambivalence
the quality and frequency of change talk during MI sessions predicts subsequent behavior change outcomes
MI is only applicable to substance use disorders and has no evidence base for other health behaviors
in MI the client, not the therapist, should be the one voicing the arguments for change

questions.explanation: MI is collaborative, person-centered, and respects autonomy (correct). MI explicitly avoids confrontation — 'rolling with resistance' is a core principle (incorrect). Complex reflections like double-sided reflections are indeed more advanced tools for illuminating ambivalence (correct). Research consistently shows that in-session change talk predicts outcomes (correct). MI was originally developed for substance use but has extensive evidence across health behaviors including diet, exercise, medication adherence, and chronic disease management (incorrect). MI posits that the client should voice arguments for change to avoid eliciting sustain talk (correct).

questions.stem: Highlight ALL statements that accurately describe the Transtheoretical Model (Stages of Change).
questions.passage: The Transtheoretical Model was developed by Prochaska and DiClemente and proposes that behavior change is a process that unfolds through stages. [In the precontemplation stage, individuals are unaware of or unwilling to acknowledge the problem and have no intention to change in the foreseeable future]. The model suggests that [people always progress through the stages in a strict linear sequence without cycling back to earlier stages]. According to the TTM, [the contemplation stage is characterized by ambivalence, with the person simultaneously recognizing the problem and being uncertain about committing to change]. Research on the TTM has shown that [matching interventions to the client's stage of change produces better outcomes than mismatched interventions]. Furthermore, [the action stage requires considerable commitment of time and energy and involves active modification of behavior]. Some critics argue that [the TTM is limited because it only applies to addictive behaviors and cannot be used with other types of behavior change].

highlightableSegments.text: In the precontemplation stage, individuals are unaware of or unwilling to acknowledge the problem and have no intention to change in the foreseeable future
people always progress through the stages in a strict linear sequence without cycling back to earlier stages
the contemplation stage is characterized by ambivalence, with the person simultaneously recognizing the problem and being uncertain about committing to change
matching interventions to the client's stage of change produces better outcomes than mismatched interventions
the action stage requires considerable commitment of time and energy and involves active modification of behavior
the TTM is limited because it only applies to addictive behaviors and cannot be used with other types of behavior change

questions.explanation: Precontemplation involves no awareness or intention to change (correct). The TTM explicitly recognizes that people often cycle through stages non-linearly, including relapsing back to earlier stages (incorrect — the spiral model). Contemplation is defined by ambivalence (correct). Stage-matched interventions are a core application of the TTM (correct). The action stage requires significant commitment and active behavioral modification (correct). The TTM was originally developed for smoking cessation but has been applied to exercise, diet, medication adherence, psychotherapy attendance, and many other behaviors (incorrect).

questions.stem: Arrange the stages of Prochaska and DiClemente's Transtheoretical Model in the correct sequential order, from earliest to latest.

items.text: Maintenance — sustaining the change over time and preventing relapse
Contemplation — aware of the problem, weighing pros and cons, ambivalent
Precontemplation — not yet considering change, unaware or in denial
Action — actively modifying behavior, requiring commitment and energy
Preparation — intending to take action soon, making small preliminary steps
Termination — the change is fully integrated and no temptation remains

questions.explanation: The Transtheoretical Model progresses through: (1) Precontemplation — no awareness of the problem; (2) Contemplation — aware but ambivalent; (3) Preparation — intending to act soon; (4) Action — actively changing behavior; (5) Maintenance — sustaining change and preventing relapse; (6) Termination — change is fully integrated with no temptation. Note that Prochaska and DiClemente described the termination stage as the ultimate goal where the individual has zero temptation and 100% self-efficacy, though not all individuals reach this stage.

questions.stem: Arrange the four processes of Motivational Interviewing (Miller & Rollnick, 2013) in the correct sequential order from the beginning of therapy.

items.text: Evoking — eliciting the client's own motivations for change (the 'heart' of MI)
Focusing — developing and maintaining a specific direction for the conversation
Engaging — establishing a working relationship and mutual trust
Planning — developing commitment to change and formulating an action plan
Consolidating — reviewing the change plan and scheduling follow-up
Implementing — the client carries out the plan between sessions with therapist monitoring

questions.explanation: Miller and Rollnick's (2013) four-process model of MI flows: (1) Engaging — building the therapeutic relationship and rapport, the foundation for everything; (2) Focusing — identifying the target of change and maintaining direction; (3) Evoking — drawing out the client's own arguments for change, the essential heart of MI; (4) Planning — formulating a concrete action plan when the client is ready. Consolidating and implementing follow naturally but are not formally named as distinct MI processes. These processes are overlapping and recursive rather than strictly linear.

questions.stem: A researcher examines the relationship between number of MI sessions completed and client readiness to change (measured on a 1-10 readiness ruler) in two groups: one receiving MI and one receiving standard psychoeducation.
questions.question: Which of the following conclusions is BEST supported by the data?

options.text: MI produced a faster and greater increase in readiness to change compared to psychoeducation alone
Both groups showed equivalent improvement in readiness to change over time
Psychoeducation was more effective than MI in the early sessions but MI caught up later
Neither intervention produced meaningful changes in readiness to change

questions.explanation: The MI group showed a steep increase in readiness from 3.2 to 8.0 (a gain of 4.8 points), while the psychoeducation group showed only a modest increase from 3.1 to 4.5 (a gain of 1.4 points). The MI group's improvement was both faster and larger at every time point. This is consistent with research showing that MI's emphasis on evoking the client's own motivations is more effective at building readiness than information-giving alone.

questions.stem: A study tracks the frequency of change talk and sustain talk utterances across four MI sessions for a client working on reducing alcohol consumption.
questions.question: Which of the following interpretations is MOST consistent with the data and MI theory?

options.text: The client is likely moving through the stages of change toward greater readiness for action, as increasing change talk relative to sustain talk predicts behavior change
The decrease in sustain talk indicates the therapist successfully confronted and eliminated the client's denial
The increase in change talk is clinically meaningless because total utterances increased
The therapist should be concerned because sustain talk has not been completely eliminated

questions.explanation: MI research demonstrates that the ratio of change talk to sustain talk is a key predictor of behavior change outcomes. The shift from predominantly sustain talk (Session 1: 20 sustain vs. 8 change) to predominantly change talk (Session 4: 5 sustain vs. 28 change) suggests the client is resolving ambivalence and moving toward action. This shift results from skillful MI practice (selectively reinforcing change talk), not from confrontation. Some sustain talk is expected and normal even as the client progresses.

questions.stem: Categorize each therapeutic technique according to the brief therapy approach it is MOST strongly associated with.

items.text: OARS skills (Open questions, Affirmations, Reflections, Summaries)
The miracle question to envision a preferred future
Interpersonal inventory reviewing significant relationships
Eliciting and reinforcing change talk using DARN-CAT
Scaling questions to rate current experience and identify next steps
Assigning the sick role to legitimize the patient's need for help

questions.explanation: MI techniques include OARS skills and eliciting change talk (DARN-CAT) — both focus on evoking the client's own motivation for change. SFBT techniques include the miracle question (envisioning a solution) and scaling questions (quantifying progress) — both focus on solutions rather than problems. IPT techniques include the interpersonal inventory (reviewing relationships) and assigning the sick role (legitimizing help-seeking) — both address interpersonal functioning within a medical model framework.

questions.stem: Categorize each client statement as representing either change talk or sustain talk, and whether it is preparatory or mobilizing (for change talk).

items.text: 'I want to be a better father to my kids' (Desire)
'I will call the treatment center tomorrow morning' (Commitment)
'I don't think my drinking is really that bad compared to my friends'
'I have to get this under control before I lose my job' (Need)
'I actually went to an AA meeting last Tuesday' (Taking steps)
'Quitting just isn't realistic right now with everything going on'

questions.explanation: Preparatory change talk (DARN) includes Desire ('I want to...') and Need ('I have to...'). Mobilizing change talk (CAT) includes Commitment ('I will...') and Taking steps ('I actually did...'). Sustain talk includes minimization ('not really that bad') and reasons to maintain the status quo ('not realistic right now'). Research shows that mobilizing change talk is more strongly predictive of actual behavior change than preparatory change talk, and that a high ratio of change talk to sustain talk predicts outcomes.
